thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: GOP cheer Trump's SCOTUS pick, Dems fret for women's rights
thread.title_full: GOP cheer Trump's SCOTUS pick, Dems fret for women's rights

author: NICOLE HENSLEY
title: GOP cheer Trump's SCOTUS pick, Dems fret for women's rights
text:
GOP senators cheer Trump's SCOTUS pick of Judge Neil Gorsuch, Democrats fret for women's and worker rights GOP cheer Trump's SCOTUS pick, Dems fret for women's rights White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon (L) and White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus (R) watch as U.S. President Donald Trump announces his SCOTUS nominee (CARLOS BARRIA/REUTERS)  31 PM 
Right-wing lawmakers applauded President Trump’s SCOTUS pick as a much-desired choice to replace former Justice Antonin Scalia while Democrats warned Judge Neil Gorsuch is far more conservative than his predecessor. 
Minutes after Trump introduced Gorsuch at the White House, Democratic National Committee circulated a fact sheet slamming the Denver judge as a “reliable right wing ideologue” with a penchant for siding with corporate clients over works, religious objections over reproductive health. 
“The nomination of Judge Gorsuch raises some very serious questions about whether he would be a Supreme Court Justice who believes the Constitution protects all of us, not just the wealth,” DNC spokeswoman Adrienne Watson said in a statement. 
Many senators, especially those stonewalled former President Obama’s Merrick Garland nomination, cheered Trump’s Supreme Court choice, even those regularly critical of Trump. 
“Awesome,” Sen. Mike Lee (R-Utah) said of the Gorsuch nomination. US President Donald Trump walks through the Cross Hall to the East Room to nominate Neil M. Gorsuch to take Justice Antonin Scalia's vacancy. (BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP/Getty Images) 
Another Trump naysayer during the presidential campaign, Sen. Ben Sasse (R-Neb.), borrowed Trump lingo to express his enthusiasm. 
“It’s a tremendous pick. He’s a rockstar,” Sasse told the Daily News. “He’s a judge’s judge. Every American should be proud.” 
Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.) accused the GOP of “packing” the Supreme Court. 
“This is the first time in American history that one party has blockaded a nominee for almost a year in order to deliver a seat to a President of their own party,” Merkley said in a statement. U.S. President Donald Trump (R) shakes hands with Judge Neil Gorsuch after nominating him to the Supreme Court during a ceremony in the East Room.   
“This is a stolen seat being filled by an illegitimate and extreme nominee, and I will do everything in my power to stand up against this assault on the Court.” 
Sen. Bernie Sanders (D-Vt.) echoed cries from the DNC for Gorsuch to "explain his hostility to women's rights, support of corporations over workers and opposition to campaign finance reform." 
Another failed presidential hopeful, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), urged Gorsuch’s confirmation and noted that in 2006, he was easily appointed to the U.S. Court of Appeals in Denver under George W. Bush’s administration. 
"I hope that each Democratic senator asks 'what's changed,' what is different from a judge they were prepared to confirm to the court of appeals... On any assessment of qualifications, on any assessment of his record being faithful to the law, Judge Gorsuch should be confirmed to the Supreme Court,” Cruz said. 
A spokeswoman for Trump’s pending Attorney General pick, Jeff Sessions, celebrated the SCOTUS nomination an early “Christmas” present for conservatives.
